conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks a light source, preventing light from reaching the surface behind the object.
The shape and size of the shadow depend on the shape of the object, the position of the light source, and the distance between the object and the surface.
When the light source is higher, shadows are generally shorter and more compact.
As the light source moves downward, shadows become longer and more elongated because the light rays hit the objects at a more oblique angle.

The shadows are already elongated, indicating that the light source is not directly overhead.
As the light source moves downward, the angle at which light rays strike the objects becomes more horizontal.
This will cause the shadows to stretch further away from the objects, making them longer.
The direction of the elongation will be along the line connecting the object and the point where the shadow falls.
